Women fill out applications at a job fair in Florida in January. Associated Press Good morning. Big companies such as Amazon.com Inc. and Wells Fargo & Co. have told recruiters not to ask about compensation job candidates received in previous roles, as more employers shift away from using past wages as a guide for setting their future pay, reports the Wall Street Journal’s Kelsey Gee .
The move stems from a slew of new laws around the U.S. aimed at closing wage gaps in the workforce. The theory behind them is that using past salaries to benchmark future pay can perpetuate unfairly high or low wages that workers carry from job to job.
Massachusetts and New York City passed laws in 2016 banning employers in those places from pressing job seekers to disclose their salary history. More than a dozen cities and states have followed suit .
“These new laws have created a great opportunity for employers to do some self-reflection,” said Cheryl Pinarchick, a partner at Fisher & Phillips LLP and co-chair of the law firm’s pay equity practice. Many are thinking about whether they can justify differences in the salaries that their current workers earn, she said.
Every week, Ms. Pinarchick’s firm gets new requests from employers who want help with audits of their pay practices, a volume that is up 10-fold from two years ago, she said.
An appeals court ruled last week that businesses may be held liable for discrepancies in their workers’ pay, even if the imbalance stems from a previous employer, adding further pressure to correct pay gaps based on gender, race or other nonperformance related factors.
“We’ve seen a lot of clients adopting the spirit of law, understanding bans on salary-history inquiries are about pay equity,” said Mollie Mantia, director of compliance for the talent arm of Automatic Data Processing Inc., a payroll management firm.
EXCLUSIVE ON RISK AND COMPLIANCE JOURNAL
U.S places sanctions on Syrian group. The Trump administration accused a Syrian organization of attempting to smuggle migrants to the U.S. border, imposing sanctions on the group and its leader, Nasif Barakat. As a result of the sanctions, all of Mr. Barakat’s U.S. assets, and those of his organization, are frozen.
COMPLIANCE
Cryptocurrency firms seek a break on oversight. Big Silicon Valley backers of cryptocurrencies have sought a broad exemption from federal oversight they say would slow digital-coin growth, the WSJ reports. The Securities and Exchange Commission has said virtual tokens issued by startups are investments that should be regulated as securities.
CFPB chief warns against leaks. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s acting director, Mick Mulvaney, warned staff not to leak information about the bureau’s enforcement work, targeting what he has called “ideologues and activists” inside the agency. In a memo last week, Mr. Mulvaney said he supports “appropriate disciplinary and other actions” against offenders, the WSJ reports.
Fox rejected higher Comcast bid due to antitrust fears. 21st Century Fox Inc. rejected an acquisition offer for its entertainment assets from cable giant Comcast Corp. largely over antitrust concerns, a regulatory filing said, even though the bid was 16% higher on a per-share basis than what Walt Disney Co. ultimately agreed to pay, the WSJ reports.
GOVERNANCE
Wynn Resorts adds women to board. Wynn Resorts added three women to its board as it addresses the fallout from sexual-misconduct allegations against former Chief Executive Steve Wynn. The move Wednesday came a day after the casino operator’s largest shareholder, Mr. Wynn’s ex-wife Elaine Wynn, demanded the board overhaul its membership, the WSJ reports. The board now has four women and seven men.
REPUTATION
Ernst & Young partner files harassment claim. A tax partner at Ernst & Young LLP filed a sexual-harassment complaint against the accounting firm, alleging another partner groped and assaulted her in 2015 and that the firm hasn’t taken the matter seriously. The accused partner has been placed on administrative leave, as new information was brought to the firm’s attention last week. Ernst & Young said it is investigating, the WSJ reports.
RISK
Chinese regulator is downbeat on NXP deal. China’s antitrust regulator gave an initial pessimistic review of Qualcomm ’s $44 billion purchase of NXP Semiconductors . A Commerce Ministry spokesman said a preliminary review turned up “related issues that are hard to resolve, making it difficult to eliminate the negative impact.” Qualcomm didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment, the WSJ reports.
Temporary nationalization is possibility for Rusal. A Kremlin spokesman said temporary nationalization by the Russian government is one option for helping the aluminum producer Rusal as it struggles with U.S. sanctions, Reuters reports. It wasn’t clear what temporary nationalization would mean, or how it would help Rusal.
EU to pitch a trade deal to Trump. The European Union is drawing up an offer it hopes will end trade hostilities with the U.S. and avoid steel and aluminum tariffs being imposed on the bloc in two weeks’ time. The key element is a simpler, smaller version of a trade deal that was negotiated but never concluded under the Obama administration, the WSJ reports.
Risks from China tariffs are unbalanced. China is a significant source of materials for only a small fraction of products on President Donald Trump’s proposed list of tariffs, but they could disproportionately hit some U.S. manufacturers that depend on Chinese imports by driving up costs and forcing them to raise prices, the WSJ reports.
OPERATIONS
IRS struggles with old computer systems. A hardware failure at the Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday that prevented taxpayers from filing online returns highlights the risks for chief information officers struggling with aging backend IT systems, tight budgets and growing pressure to provide innovative front-end services, the WSJ reports.
STRATEGY
P&G to buy Merck business. Procter & Gamble Co. agreed to acquire the consumer-health business from Germany’s Merck KGaA , in a $4.2 billion deal that adds vitamins and food supplements to its lineup of over-the-counter medicines. The deal is one of the biggest acquisitions in recent years for Procter & Gamble, the WSJ reports.
Packages of Procter & Gamble’s detergent. The company is buying a unit from Merck KGaA. PHOTO: RICHARD B. LEVINE/ZUMA PRESS Facebook plans to build own chips. Facebook Inc. is planning to design chips that could be used in its consumer devices, artificial-intelligence software and data centers, the WSJ reports. The effort is part of the social-media company’s nascent push to develop more of its own hardware.
Bon-Ton to liquidate stores. Bon-Ton Stores will shut its remaining outlets and go out of business after a bankruptcy judge said she would approve the sale of the department-store operator’s assets. Bondholders and a pair of liquidators will begin closing more than 250 stores across 23 states, the WSJ reports, putting about 24,000 employees out of work.
